newsitem.title: UK: UK card spending up 18.9 pct yr/yr in May - CCRG.
newsitem.headline: UK card spending up 18.9 pct yr/yr in May - CCRG.

text.p: The Credit Card Research Group, representing major UK credit and debit card issuers, released the following consumer spending figures for May 1997 -
CARD EXPENDITURE (in million stg) *MAY MAY 96 % change
NOTE * figures adjusted for variations in the number of processing days between months.
Credit Card Research Group director Elizabeth Phillips said shopping in anticipation of building society windfalls pushed credit and debit card spending to 8.2 billion stg.
Consumers were reinvesting their windfall gains in their homes, borne out by a 35.3 percent rise in the household, but weren't going wild, the report said.
"The card spending figures for May indicate that in the wake of the general election consumer spending remains strong rather than spectacular," Phillips said.
The 14 percent yr/yr increase in credit card spending to over 4.5 billion stg was in line with recent trends.

The largest annual rises in credit card expenditure were in the household, food and drink sectors. The travel sector, however, rose by just 10 percent due to credit card payment surcharges imposed by travel agents, the report said. -- Simon Gardner +44 171 542 7708
